00032 // Low-level types and utilities for porting Google Test to various
00033 // platforms.  They are subject to change without notice.  DO NOT USE
00034 // THEM IN USER CODE.
00035 
00036 #ifndef GTEST_INCLUDE_GTEST_INTERNAL_GTEST_PORT_H_
00037 #define GTEST_INCLUDE_GTEST_INTERNAL_GTEST_PORT_H_
00038 
00039 // The user can define the following macros in the build script to
00040 // control Google Test's behavior.  If the user doesn't define a macro
00041 // in this list, Google Test will define it.
00042 //
00043 //   GTEST_HAS_CLONE          - Define it to 1/0 to indicate that clone(2)
00044 //                              is/isn't available.
00045 //   GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_STRING  - Define it to 1/0 to indicate that ::string
00046 //                              is/isn't available (some systems define
00047 //                              ::string, which is different to std::string).
00048 //   GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_WSTRING - Define it to 1/0 to indicate that ::string
00049 //                              is/isn't available (some systems define
00050 //                              ::wstring, which is different to std::wstring).
00051 //   GTEST_HAS_PTHREAD        - Define it to 1/0 to indicate that <pthread.h>
00052 //                              is/isn't available.
00053 //   GTEST_HAS_RTTI           - Define it to 1/0 to indicate that RTTI is/isn't
00054 //                              enabled.
00055 //   GTEST_HAS_STD_STRING     - Define it to 1/0 to indicate that
00056 //                              std::string does/doesn't work (Google Test can
00057 //                              be used where std::string is unavailable).
00058 //   GTEST_HAS_STD_WSTRING    - Define it to 1/0 to indicate that
00059 //                              std::wstring does/doesn't work (Google Test can
00060 //                              be used where std::wstring is unavailable).
00061 //   GTEST_HAS_TR1_TUPLE 1    - Define it to 1/0 to indicate tr1::tuple
00062 //                              is/isn't available.
00063 
00064 // This header defines the following utilities:
00065 //
00066 // Macros indicating the name of the Google C++ Testing Framework project:
00067 //   GTEST_NAME              - a string literal of the project name.
00068 //   GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX       - a string literal of the prefix all Google
00069 //                             Test flag names share.
00070 //   GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_UPPER - a string literal of the prefix all Google
00071 //                             Test flag names share, in upper case.
00072 //
00073 // Macros indicating the current platform:
00074 //   GTEST_OS_CYGWIN   - defined iff compiled on Cygwin.
00075 //   GTEST_OS_LINUX    - defined iff compiled on Linux.
00076 //   GTEST_OS_MAC      - defined iff compiled on Mac OS X.
00077 //   GTEST_OS_SOLARIS  - defined iff compiled on Sun Solaris.
00078 //   GTEST_OS_SYMBIAN  - defined iff compiled for Symbian.
00079 //   GTEST_OS_WINDOWS  - defined iff compiled on Windows.
00080 //   GTEST_OS_ZOS      - defined iff compiled on IBM z/OS.
00081 //
00082 // Among the platforms, Cygwin, Linux, Max OS X, and Windows have the
00083 // most stable support.  Since core members of the Google Test project
00084 // don't have access to other platforms, support for them may be less
00085 // stable.  If you notice any problems on your platform, please notify
00086 // googletestframework@googlegroups.com (patches for fixing them are
00087 // even more welcome!).
00088 //
00089 // Note that it is possible that none of the GTEST_OS_ macros are defined.
00090 //
00091 // Macros indicating available Google Test features:
00092 //   GTEST_HAS_COMBINE      - defined iff Combine construct is supported
00093 //                            in value-parameterized tests.
00094 //   GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST   - defined iff death tests are supported.
00095 //   GTEST_HAS_PARAM_TEST   - defined iff value-parameterized tests are
00096 //                            supported.
00097 //   GTEST_HAS_TYPED_TEST   - defined iff typed tests are supported.
00098 //   GTEST_HAS_TYPED_TEST_P - defined iff type-parameterized tests are
00099 //                            supported.
00100 //
00101 // Macros for basic C++ coding:
00102 //   GTEST_AMBIGUOUS_ELSE_BLOCKER_ - for disabling a gcc warning.
00103 //   GTEST_ATTRIBUTE_UNUSED_  - declares that a class' instances don't have to
00104 //                              be used.
00105 //   GTEST_DISALLOW_COPY_AND_ASSIGN_ - disables copy ctor and operator=.
00106 //   GTEST_MUST_USE_RESULT_   - declares that a function's result must be used.
00107 //
00108 // Synchronization:
00109 //   Mutex, MutexLock, ThreadLocal, GetThreadCount()
00110 //                  - synchronization primitives.
00111 //   GTEST_IS_THREADSAFE - defined to 1 to indicate that the above
00112 //                         synchronization primitives have real implementations
00113 //                         and Google Test is thread-safe; or 0 otherwise.
00114 //
00115 // Template meta programming:
00116 //   is_pointer     - as in TR1; needed on Symbian and IBM XL C/C++ only.
00117 //
00118 // Smart pointers:
00119 //   scoped_ptr     - as in TR2.
00120 //
00121 // Regular expressions:
00122 //   RE             - a simple regular expression class using the POSIX
00123 //                    Extended Regular Expression syntax.  Not available on
00124 //                    Windows.
00125 //
00126 // Logging:
00127 //   GTEST_LOG_()   - logs messages at the specified severity level.
00128 //   LogToStderr()  - directs all log messages to stderr.
00129 //   FlushInfoLog() - flushes informational log messages.
00130 //
00131 // Stderr capturing:
00132 //   CaptureStderr()     - starts capturing stderr.
00133 //   GetCapturedStderr() - stops capturing stderr and returns the captured
00134 //                         string.
00135 //
00136 // Integer types:
00137 //   TypeWithSize   - maps an integer to a int type.
00138 //   Int32, UInt32, Int64, UInt64, TimeInMillis
00139 //                  - integers of known sizes.
00140 //   BiggestInt     - the biggest signed integer type.
00141 //
00142 // Command-line utilities:
00143 //   GTEST_FLAG()       - references a flag.
00144 //   GTEST_DECLARE_*()  - declares a flag.
00145 //   GTEST_DEFINE_*()   - defines a flag.
00146 //   GetArgvs()         - returns the command line as a vector of strings.
00147 //
00148 // Environment variable utilities:
00149 //   GetEnv()             - gets the value of an environment variable.
00150 //   BoolFromGTestEnv()   - parses a bool environment variable.
00151 //   Int32FromGTestEnv()  - parses an Int32 environment variable.
00152 //   StringFromGTestEnv() - parses a string environment variable.
00153 
00154 #include <stdlib.h>
00155 #include <stdio.h>
00156 #include <iostream>  // Used for GTEST_CHECK_
00157 
00158 #define GTEST_NAME "Google Test"
00159 #define GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX "gtest_"
00160 #define GTEST_FLAG_PREFIX_UPPER "GTEST_"
00161 
00162 // Determines the version of gcc that is used to compile this.
00163 #ifdef __GNUC__
00164 // 40302 means version 4.3.2.
00165 #define GTEST_GCC_VER_ \
00166     (__GNUC__*10000 + __GNUC_MINOR__*100 + __GNUC_PATCHLEVEL__)
00167 #endif  // __GNUC__
00168 
00169 // Determines the platform on which Google Test is compiled.
00170 #ifdef __CYGWIN__
00171 #define GTEST_OS_CYGWIN
00172 #elif __SYMBIAN32__
00173 #define GTEST_OS_SYMBIAN
00174 #elif defined _MSC_VER
00175 // TODO(kenton@google.com): GTEST_OS_WINDOWS is currently used to mean
00176 //   both "The OS is Windows" and "The compiler is MSVC".  These
00177 //   meanings really should be separated in order to better support
00178 //   Windows compilers other than MSVC.
00179 #define GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
00180 #elif defined __APPLE__
00181 #define GTEST_OS_MAC
00182 #elif defined __linux__
00183 #define GTEST_OS_LINUX
00184 #elif defined __MVS__
00185 #define GTEST_OS_ZOS
00186 #elif defined(__sun) && defined(__SVR4)
00187 #define GTEST_OS_SOLARIS
00188 #endif  // _MSC_VER
00189 
00190 // Determines whether ::std::string and ::string are available.
00191 
00192 #ifndef GTEST_HAS_STD_STRING
00193 // The user didn't tell us whether ::std::string is available, so we
00194 // need to figure it out.
00195 
00196 #ifdef GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
00197 // Assumes that exceptions are enabled by default.
00198 #ifndef _HAS_EXCEPTIONS
00199 #define _HAS_EXCEPTIONS 1
00200 #endif  // _HAS_EXCEPTIONS
00201 // GTEST_HAS_EXCEPTIONS is non-zero iff exceptions are enabled.  It is
00202 // always defined, while _HAS_EXCEPTIONS is defined only on Windows.
00203 #define GTEST_HAS_EXCEPTIONS _HAS_EXCEPTIONS
00204 // On Windows, we can use ::std::string if the compiler version is VS
00205 // 2005 or above, or if exceptions are enabled.
00206 #define GTEST_HAS_STD_STRING ((_MSC_VER >= 1400) || GTEST_HAS_EXCEPTIONS)
00207 #else  // We are on Linux or Mac OS.
00208 #define GTEST_HAS_EXCEPTIONS 0
00209 #define GTEST_HAS_STD_STRING 1
00210 #endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
00211 
00212 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_STD_STRING
00213 
00214 #ifndef GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_STRING
00215 // The user didn't tell us whether ::string is available, so we need
00216 // to figure it out.
00217 
00218 #define GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_STRING 0
00219 
00220 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_STRING
00221 
00222 #ifndef GTEST_HAS_STD_WSTRING
00223 // The user didn't tell us whether ::std::wstring is available, so we need
00224 // to figure it out.
00225 // TODO(wan@google.com): uses autoconf to detect whether ::std::wstring
00226 //   is available.
00227 
00228 #if defined(GTEST_OS_CYGWIN) || defined(GTEST_OS_SOLARIS)
00229 // At least some versions of cygwin don't support ::std::wstring.
00230 // Solaris' libc++ doesn't support it either.
00231 #define GTEST_HAS_STD_WSTRING 0
00232 #else
00233 #define GTEST_HAS_STD_WSTRING GTEST_HAS_STD_STRING
00234 #endif  // defined(GTEST_OS_CYGWIN) || defined(GTEST_OS_SOLARIS)
00235 
00236 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_STD_WSTRING
00237 
00238 #ifndef GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_WSTRING
00239 // The user didn't tell us whether ::wstring is available, so we need
00240 // to figure it out.
00241 #define GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_WSTRING GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_STRING
00242 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_WSTRING
00243 
00244 #if GTEST_HAS_STD_STRING || GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_STRING || \
00245     GTEST_HAS_STD_WSTRING || GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_WSTRING
00246 #include <string>  // NOLINT
00247 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_STD_STRING || GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_STRING ||
00248         // GTEST_HAS_STD_WSTRING || GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_WSTRING
00249 
00250 #if GTEST_HAS_STD_STRING
00251 #include <sstream>  // NOLINT
00252 #else
00253 #include <strstream>  // NOLINT
00254 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_STD_STRING
00255 
00256 // Determines whether RTTI is available.
00257 #ifndef GTEST_HAS_RTTI
00258 // The user didn't tell us whether RTTI is enabled, so we need to
00259 // figure it out.
00260 
00261 #ifdef _MSC_VER
00262 
00263 #ifdef _CPPRTTI  // MSVC defines this macro iff RTTI is enabled.
00264 #define GTEST_HAS_RTTI 1
00265 #else
00266 #define GTEST_HAS_RTTI 0
00267 #endif  // _CPPRTTI
00268 
00269 #elif defined(__GNUC__)
00270 
00271 // Starting with version 4.3.2, gcc defines __GXX_RTTI iff RTTI is enabled.
00272 #if GTEST_GCC_VER_ >= 40302
00273 #ifdef __GXX_RTTI
00274 #define GTEST_HAS_RTTI 1
00275 #else
00276 #define GTEST_HAS_RTTI 0
00277 #endif  // __GXX_RTTI
00278 #else
00279 // For gcc versions smaller than 4.3.2, we assume RTTI is enabled.
00280 #define GTEST_HAS_RTTI 1
00281 #endif  // GTEST_GCC_VER >= 40302
00282 
00283 #else
00284 
00285 // Unknown compiler - assume RTTI is enabled.
00286 #define GTEST_HAS_RTTI 1
00287 
00288 #endif  // _MSC_VER
00289 
00290 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_RTTI
00291 
00292 // Determines whether <pthread.h> is available.
00293 #ifndef GTEST_HAS_PTHREAD
00294 // The user didn't tell us, so we need to figure it out.
00295 
00296 #if defined(GTEST_OS_LINUX) || defined(GTEST_OS_MAC)
00297 #define GTEST_HAS_PTHREAD 1
00298 #else
00299 #define GTEST_HAS_PTHREAD 0
00300 #endif  // GTEST_OS_LINUX || GTEST_OS_MAC
00301 
00302 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_PTHREAD
00303 
00304 // Determines whether tr1/tuple is available.  If you have tr1/tuple
00305 // on your platform, define GTEST_HAS_TR1_TUPLE=1 for both the Google
00306 // Test project and your tests. If you would like Google Test to detect
00307 // tr1/tuple on your platform automatically, please open an issue
00308 // ticket at http://code.google.com/p/googletest.
00309 #ifndef GTEST_HAS_TR1_TUPLE
00310 // The user didn't tell us, so we need to figure it out.
00311 
00312 // GCC provides <tr1/tuple> since 4.0.0.
00313 #if defined(__GNUC__) && (GTEST_GCC_VER_ >= 40000)
00314 #define GTEST_HAS_TR1_TUPLE 1
00315 #else
00316 #define GTEST_HAS_TR1_TUPLE 0
00317 #endif  // __GNUC__
00318 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_TR1_TUPLE
00319 
00320 // To avoid conditional compilation everywhere, we make it
00321 // gtest-port.h's responsibility to #include the header implementing
00322 // tr1/tuple.
00323 #if GTEST_HAS_TR1_TUPLE
00324 #if defined(__GNUC__)
00325 // GCC implements tr1/tuple in the <tr1/tuple> header.  This does not
00326 // conform to the TR1 spec, which requires the header to be <tuple>.
00327 #include <tr1/tuple>
00328 #else
00329 // If the compiler is not GCC, we assume the user is using a
00330 // spec-conforming TR1 implementation.
00331 #include <tuple>
00332 #endif  // __GNUC__
00333 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_TR1_TUPLE
00334 
00335 // Determines whether clone(2) is supported.
00336 // Usually it will only be available on Linux, excluding
00337 // Linux on the Itanium architecture.
00338 // Also see http://linux.die.net/man/2/clone.
00339 #ifndef GTEST_HAS_CLONE
00340 // The user didn't tell us, so we need to figure it out.
00341 
00342 #if defined(GTEST_OS_LINUX) && !defined(__ia64__)
00343 #define GTEST_HAS_CLONE 1
00344 #else
00345 #define GTEST_HAS_CLONE 0
00346 #endif  // defined(GTEST_OS_LINUX) && !defined(__ia64__)
00347 
00348 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_CLONE
00349 
00350 // Determines whether to support death tests.
00351 #if GTEST_HAS_STD_STRING && GTEST_HAS_CLONE
00352 #define GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
00353 // On some platforms, <regex.h> needs someone to define size_t, and
00354 // won't compile otherwise.  We can #include it here as we already
00355 // included <stdlib.h>, which is guaranteed to define size_t through
00356 // <stddef.h>.
00357 #include <regex.h>
00358 #include <vector>
00359 #include <fcntl.h>
00360 #include <sys/mman.h>
00361 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_STD_STRING && GTEST_HAS_CLONE
00362 
00363 // Determines whether to support value-parameterized tests.
00364 
00365 #if defined(__GNUC__) || (_MSC_VER >= 1400)
00366 // TODO(vladl@google.com): get the implementation rid of vector and list
00367 // to compile on MSVC 7.1.
00368 #define GTEST_HAS_PARAM_TEST
00369 #endif  // defined(__GNUC__) || (_MSC_VER >= 1400)
00370 
00371 // Determines whether to support type-driven tests.
00372 
00373 // Typed tests need <typeinfo> and variadic macros, which gcc and VC
00374 // 8.0+ support.
00375 #if defined(__GNUC__) || (_MSC_VER >= 1400)
00376 #define GTEST_HAS_TYPED_TEST
00377 #define GTEST_HAS_TYPED_TEST_P
00378 #endif  // defined(__GNUC__) || (_MSC_VER >= 1400)
00379 
00380 // Determines whether to support Combine(). This only makes sense when
00381 // value-parameterized tests are enabled.
00382 #if defined(GTEST_HAS_PARAM_TEST) && GTEST_HAS_TR1_TUPLE
00383 #define GTEST_HAS_COMBINE
00384 #endif  // defined(GTEST_HAS_PARAM_TEST) && GTEST_HAS_TR1_TUPLE
00385 
00386 // Determines whether the system compiler uses UTF-16 for encoding wide strings.
00387 #if defined(GTEST_OS_WINDOWS) || defined(GTEST_OS_CYGWIN) || \
00388         defined(GTEST_OS_SYMBIAN)
00389 #define GTEST_WIDE_STRING_USES_UTF16_ 1
00390 #endif

00392 // Defines some utility macros.
00393 
00394 // The GNU compiler emits a warning if nested "if" statements are followed by
00395 // an "else" statement and braces are not used to explicitly disambiguate the
00396 // "else" binding.  This leads to problems with code like:
00397 //
00398 //   if (gate)
00399 //     ASSERT_*(condition) << "Some message";
00400 //
00401 // The "switch (0) case 0:" idiom is used to suppress this.
00402 #ifdef __INTEL_COMPILER
00403 #define GTEST_AMBIGUOUS_ELSE_BLOCKER_
00404 #else
00405 #define GTEST_AMBIGUOUS_ELSE_BLOCKER_ switch (0) case 0:  // NOLINT
00406 #endif
00407 
00408 // Use this annotation at the end of a struct / class definition to
00409 // prevent the compiler from optimizing away instances that are never
00410 // used.  This is useful when all interesting logic happens inside the
00411 // c'tor and / or d'tor.  Example:
00412 //
00413 //   struct Foo {
00414 //     Foo() { ... }
00415 //   } GTEST_ATTRIBUTE_UNUSED_;
00416 #if defined(__GNUC__) && !defined(COMPILER_ICC)
00417 #define GTEST_ATTRIBUTE_UNUSED_ __attribute__ ((unused))
00418 #else
00419 #define GTEST_ATTRIBUTE_UNUSED_
00420 #endif
00421 
00422 // A macro to disallow the evil copy constructor and operator= functions
00423 // This should be used in the private: declarations for a class.
00424 #define GTEST_DISALLOW_COPY_AND_ASSIGN_(type)\
00425   type(const type &);\
00426   void operator=(const type &)
00427 
00428 // Tell the compiler to warn about unused return values for functions declared
00429 // with this macro.  The macro should be used on function declarations
00430 // following the argument list:
00431 //
00432 //   Sprocket* AllocateSprocket() GTEST_MUST_USE_RESULT_;
00433 #if defined(__GNUC__) && (GTEST_GCC_VER_ >= 30400) && !defined(COMPILER_ICC)
00434 #define GTEST_MUST_USE_RESULT_ __attribute__ ((warn_unused_result))
00435 #else
00436 #define GTEST_MUST_USE_RESULT_
00437 #endif  // __GNUC__ && (GTEST_GCC_VER_ >= 30400) && !COMPILER_ICC
00438 
00439 namespace testing {
00440 
00441 class Message;
00442 
00443 namespace internal {
00444 
00445 class String;
00446 
00447 // std::strstream is deprecated.  However, we have to use it on
00448 // Windows as std::stringstream won't compile on Windows when
00449 // exceptions are disabled.  We use std::stringstream on other
00450 // platforms to avoid compiler warnings there.
00451 #if GTEST_HAS_STD_STRING
00452 typedef ::std::stringstream StrStream;
00453 #else
00454 typedef ::std::strstream StrStream;
00455 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_STD_STRING
00456 
00457 // Defines scoped_ptr.
00458 
00459 // This implementation of scoped_ptr is PARTIAL - it only contains
00460 // enough stuff to satisfy Google Test's need.
00461 template <typename T>
00462 class scoped_ptr {
00463  public:
00464   explicit scoped_ptr(T* p = NULL) : ptr_(p) {}
00465   ~scoped_ptr() { reset(); }
00466 
00467   T& operator*() const { return *ptr_; }
00468   T* operator->() const { return ptr_; }
00469   T* get() const { return ptr_; }
00470 
00471   T* release() {
00472     T* const ptr = ptr_;
00473     ptr_ = NULL;
00474     return ptr;
00475   }
00476 
00477   void reset(T* p = NULL) {
00478     if (p != ptr_) {
00479       if (sizeof(T) > 0) {  // Makes sure T is a complete type.
00480         delete ptr_;
00481       }
00482       ptr_ = p;
00483     }
00484   }
00485  private:
00486   T* ptr_;
00487 
00488   GTEST_DISALLOW_COPY_AND_ASSIGN_(scoped_ptr);
00489 };
00490 
00491 #ifdef GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
00492 
00493 // Defines RE.
00494 
00495 // A simple C++ wrapper for <regex.h>.  It uses the POSIX Enxtended
00496 // Regular Expression syntax.
00497 class RE {
00498  public:
00499   // Constructs an RE from a string.
00500 #if GTEST_HAS_STD_STRING
00501   RE(const ::std::string& regex) { Init(regex.c_str()); }  // NOLINT
00502 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_STD_STRING
00503 
00504 #if GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_STRING
00505   RE(const ::string& regex) { Init(regex.c_str()); }  // NOLINT
00506 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_STRING
00507 
00508   RE(const char* regex) { Init(regex); }  // NOLINT
00509   ~RE();
00510 
00511   // Returns the string representation of the regex.
00512   const char* pattern() const { return pattern_; }
00513 
00514   // FullMatch(str, re) returns true iff regular expression re matches
00515   // the entire str.
00516   // PartialMatch(str, re) returns true iff regular expression re
00517   // matches a substring of str (including str itself).
00518   //
00519   // TODO(wan@google.com): make FullMatch() and PartialMatch() work
00520   // when str contains NUL characters.
00521 #if GTEST_HAS_STD_STRING
00522   static bool FullMatch(const ::std::string& str, const RE& re) {
00523     return FullMatch(str.c_str(), re);
00524   }
00525   static bool PartialMatch(const ::std::string& str, const RE& re) {
00526     return PartialMatch(str.c_str(), re);
00527   }
00528 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_STD_STRING
00529 
00530 #if GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_STRING
00531   static bool FullMatch(const ::string& str, const RE& re) {
00532     return FullMatch(str.c_str(), re);
00533   }
00534   static bool PartialMatch(const ::string& str, const RE& re) {
00535     return PartialMatch(str.c_str(), re);
00536   }
00537 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_STRING
00538 
00539   static bool FullMatch(const char* str, const RE& re);
00540   static bool PartialMatch(const char* str, const RE& re);
00541 
00542  private:
00543   void Init(const char* regex);
00544 
00545   // We use a const char* instead of a string, as Google Test may be used
00546   // where string is not available.  We also do not use Google Test's own
00547   // String type here, in order to simplify dependencies between the
00548   // files.
00549   const char* pattern_;
00550   regex_t full_regex_;     // For FullMatch().
00551   regex_t partial_regex_;  // For PartialMatch().
00552   bool is_valid_;
00553 };
00554 
00555 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
00556 
00557 // Defines logging utilities:
00558 //   GTEST_LOG_()   - logs messages at the specified severity level.
00559 //   LogToStderr()  - directs all log messages to stderr.
00560 //   FlushInfoLog() - flushes informational log messages.
00561 
00562 enum GTestLogSeverity {
00563   GTEST_INFO,
00564   GTEST_WARNING,
00565   GTEST_ERROR,
00566   GTEST_FATAL
00567 };
00568 
00569 void GTestLog(GTestLogSeverity severity, const char* file,
00570               int line, const char* msg);
00571 
00572 #define GTEST_LOG_(severity, msg)\
00573     ::testing::internal::GTestLog(\
00574         ::testing::internal::GTEST_##severity, __FILE__, __LINE__, \
00575         (::testing::Message() << (msg)).GetString().c_str())
00576 
00577 inline void LogToStderr() {}
00578 inline void FlushInfoLog() { fflush(NULL); }
00579 
00580 // Defines the stderr capturer:
00581 //   CaptureStderr     - starts capturing stderr.
00582 //   GetCapturedStderr - stops capturing stderr and returns the captured string.
00583 
00584 #ifdef GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
00585 
00586 // A copy of all command line arguments.  Set by InitGoogleTest().
00587 extern ::std::vector<String> g_argvs;
00588 
00589 void CaptureStderr();

00591 ::std::string GetCapturedStderr();
00592 const ::std::vector<String>& GetArgvs();

00596 // Defines synchronization primitives.
00597 
00598 // A dummy implementation of synchronization primitives (mutex, lock,
00599 // and thread-local variable).  Necessary for compiling Google Test where
00600 // mutex is not supported - using Google Test in multiple threads is not
00601 // supported on such platforms.
00602 
00603 class Mutex {
00604  public:
00605   Mutex() {}
00606   explicit Mutex(int /*unused*/) {}
00607   void AssertHeld() const {}
00608   enum { NO_CONSTRUCTOR_NEEDED_FOR_STATIC_MUTEX = 0 };
00609 };
00610 
00611 // We cannot call it MutexLock directly as the ctor declaration would
00612 // conflict with a macro named MutexLock, which is defined on some
00613 // platforms.  Hence the typedef trick below.
00614 class GTestMutexLock {
00615  public:
00616   explicit GTestMutexLock(Mutex*) {}  // NOLINT
00617 };
00618 
00619 typedef GTestMutexLock MutexLock;
00620 
00621 template <typename T>
00622 class ThreadLocal {
00623  public:
00624   ThreadLocal() : value_() {}
00625   explicit ThreadLocal(const T& value) : value_(value) {}
00626   T* pointer() { return &value_; }
00627   const T* pointer() const { return &value_; }
00628   const T& get() const { return value_; }
00629   void set(const T& value) { value_ = value; }
00630  private:
00631   T value_;
00632 };
00633 
00634 // There's no portable way to detect the number of threads, so we just
00635 // return 0 to indicate that we cannot detect it.
00636 inline size_t GetThreadCount() { return 0; }
00637 
00638 // The above synchronization primitives have dummy implementations.
00639 // Therefore Google Test is not thread-safe.
00640 #define GTEST_IS_THREADSAFE 0
00641 
00642 #if defined(__SYMBIAN32__) || defined(__IBMCPP__)
00643 
00644 // Passing non-POD classes through ellipsis (...) crashes the ARM
00645 // compiler.  The Nokia Symbian and the IBM XL C/C++ compiler try to
00646 // instantiate a copy constructor for objects passed through ellipsis
00647 // (...), failing for uncopyable objects.  We define this to indicate
00648 // the fact.
00649 #define GTEST_ELLIPSIS_NEEDS_COPY_ 1
00650 
00651 // The Nokia Symbian and IBM XL C/C++ compilers cannot decide between
00652 // const T& and const T* in a function template.  These compilers
00653 // _can_ decide between class template specializations for T and T*,
00654 // so a tr1::type_traits-like is_pointer works.
00655 #define GTEST_NEEDS_IS_POINTER_ 1
00656 
00657 #endif  // defined(__SYMBIAN32__) || defined(__IBMCPP__)
00658 
00659 template <bool bool_value>
00660 struct bool_constant {
00661   typedef bool_constant<bool_value> type;
00662   static const bool value = bool_value;
00663 };
00664 template <bool bool_value> const bool bool_constant<bool_value>::value;
00665 
00666 typedef bool_constant<false> false_type;
00667 typedef bool_constant<true> true_type;
00668 
00669 template <typename T>
00670 struct is_pointer : public false_type {};
00671 
00672 template <typename T>
00673 struct is_pointer<T*> : public true_type {};
00674 
00675 // Defines BiggestInt as the biggest signed integer type the compiler
00676 // supports.
00677 
00678 #ifdef GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
00679 typedef __int64 BiggestInt;
00680 #else
00681 typedef long long BiggestInt;  // NOLINT
00682 #endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
00683 
00684 // The maximum number a BiggestInt can represent.  This definition
00685 // works no matter BiggestInt is represented in one's complement or
00686 // two's complement.
00687 //
00688 // We cannot rely on numeric_limits in STL, as __int64 and long long
00689 // are not part of standard C++ and numeric_limits doesn't need to be
00690 // defined for them.
00691 const BiggestInt kMaxBiggestInt =
00692     ~(static_cast<BiggestInt>(1) << (8*sizeof(BiggestInt) - 1));
00693 
00694 // This template class serves as a compile-time function from size to
00695 // type.  It maps a size in bytes to a primitive type with that
00696 // size. e.g.
00697 //
00698 //   TypeWithSize<4>::UInt
00699 //
00700 // is typedef-ed to be unsigned int (unsigned integer made up of 4
00701 // bytes).
00702 //
00703 // Such functionality should belong to STL, but I cannot find it
00704 // there.
00705 //
00706 // Google Test uses this class in the implementation of floating-point
00707 // comparison.
00708 //
00709 // For now it only handles UInt (unsigned int) as that's all Google Test
00710 // needs.  Other types can be easily added in the future if need
00711 // arises.
00712 template <size_t size>
00713 class TypeWithSize {
00714  public:
00715   // This prevents the user from using TypeWithSize<N> with incorrect
00716   // values of N.
00717   typedef void UInt;
00718 };
00719 
00720 // The specialization for size 4.
00721 template <>
00722 class TypeWithSize<4> {
00723  public:
00724   // unsigned int has size 4 in both gcc and MSVC.
00725   //
00726   // As base/basictypes.h doesn't compile on Windows, we cannot use
00727   // uint32, uint64, and etc here.
00728   typedef int Int;
00729   typedef unsigned int UInt;
00730 };
00731 
00732 // The specialization for size 8.
00733 template <>
00734 class TypeWithSize<8> {
00735  public:
00736 #ifdef GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
00737   typedef __int64 Int;
00738   typedef unsigned __int64 UInt;
00739 #else
00740   typedef long long Int;  // NOLINT
00741   typedef unsigned long long UInt;  // NOLINT
00742 #endif  // GTEST_OS_WINDOWS
00743 };
00744 
00745 // Integer types of known sizes.
00746 typedef TypeWithSize<4>::Int Int32;
00747 typedef TypeWithSize<4>::UInt UInt32;
00748 typedef TypeWithSize<8>::Int Int64;
00749 typedef TypeWithSize<8>::UInt UInt64;
00750 typedef TypeWithSize<8>::Int TimeInMillis;  // Represents time in milliseconds.
00751 
00752 // Utilities for command line flags and environment variables.
00753 
00754 // A wrapper for getenv() that works on Linux, Windows, and Mac OS.
00755 inline const char* GetEnv(const char* name) {
00756 #ifdef _WIN32_WCE  // We are on Windows CE.
00757   // CE has no environment variables.
00758   return NULL;
00759 #elif defined(GTEST_OS_WINDOWS)  // We are on Windows proper.
00760   // MSVC 8 deprecates getenv(), so we want to suppress warning 4996
00761   // (deprecated function) there.
00762 #pragma warning(push)          // Saves the current warning state.
00763 #pragma warning(disable:4996)  // Temporarily disables warning 4996.
00764   return getenv(name);
00765 #pragma warning(pop)           // Restores the warning state.
00766 #else  // We are on Linux or Mac OS.
00767   return getenv(name);
00768 #endif
00769 }
00770 
00771 #ifdef _WIN32_WCE
00772 // Windows CE has no C library. The abort() function is used in
00773 // several places in Google Test. This implementation provides a reasonable
00774 // imitation of standard behaviour.
00775 void abort();
00776 #else
00777 inline void abort() { ::abort(); }
00778 #endif  // _WIN32_WCE
00779 
00780 // INTERNAL IMPLEMENTATION - DO NOT USE.
00781 //
00782 // GTEST_CHECK_ is an all-mode assert. It aborts the program if the condition
00783 // is not satisfied.
00784 //  Synopsys:
00785 //    GTEST_CHECK_(boolean_condition);
00786 //     or
00787 //    GTEST_CHECK_(boolean_condition) << "Additional message";
00788 //
00789 //    This checks the condition and if the condition is not satisfied
00790 //    it prints message about the condition violation, including the
00791 //    condition itself, plus additional message streamed into it, if any,
00792 //    and then it aborts the program. It aborts the program irrespective of
00793 //    whether it is built in the debug mode or not.
00794 class GTestCheckProvider {
00795  public:
00796   GTestCheckProvider(const char* condition, const char* file, int line) {
00797     FormatFileLocation(file, line);
00798     ::std::cerr << " ERROR: Condition " << condition << " failed. ";
00799   }
00800   ~GTestCheckProvider() {
00801     ::std::cerr << ::std::endl;
00802     abort();
00803   }
00804   void FormatFileLocation(const char* file, int line) {
00805     if (file == NULL)
00806       file = "unknown file";
00807     if (line < 0) {
00808       ::std::cerr << file << ":";
00809     } else {
00810 #if _MSC_VER
00811       ::std::cerr << file << "(" << line << "):";
00812 #else
00813       ::std::cerr << file << ":" << line << ":";
00814 #endif
00815     }
00816   }
00817   ::std::ostream& GetStream() { return ::std::cerr; }
00818 };
00819 #define GTEST_CHECK_(condition) \
00820     GTEST_AMBIGUOUS_ELSE_BLOCKER_ \
00821     if (condition) \
00822       ; \
00823     else \
00824       ::testing::internal::GTestCheckProvider(\
00825           #condition, __FILE__, __LINE__).GetStream()
00826 
00827 // Macro for referencing flags.
00828 #define GTEST_FLAG(name) FLAGS_gtest_##name
00829 
00830 // Macros for declaring flags.
00831 #define GTEST_DECLARE_bool_(name) extern bool GTEST_FLAG(name)
00832 #define GTEST_DECLARE_int32_(name) \
00833     extern ::testing::internal::Int32 GTEST_FLAG(name)
00834 #define GTEST_DECLARE_string_(name) \
00835     extern ::testing::internal::String GTEST_FLAG(name)
00836 
00837 // Macros for defining flags.
00838 #define GTEST_DEFINE_bool_(name, default_val, doc) \
00839     bool GTEST_FLAG(name) = (default_val)
00840 #define GTEST_DEFINE_int32_(name, default_val, doc) \
00841     ::testing::internal::Int32 GTEST_FLAG(name) = (default_val)
00842 #define GTEST_DEFINE_string_(name, default_val, doc) \
00843     ::testing::internal::String GTEST_FLAG(name) = (default_val)
00844 
00845 // Parses 'str' for a 32-bit signed integer.  If successful, writes the result
00846 // to *value and returns true; otherwise leaves *value unchanged and returns
00847 // false.
00848 // TODO(chandlerc): Find a better way to refactor flag and environment parsing
00849 // out of both gtest-port.cc and gtest.cc to avoid exporting this utility
00850 // function.
00851 bool ParseInt32(const Message& src_text, const char* str, Int32* value);

00854 // corresponding to the given Google Test flag.
00855 bool BoolFromGTestEnv(const char* flag, bool default_val);
00856 Int32 Int32FromGTestEnv(const char* flag, Int32 default_val);
00857 const char* StringFromGTestEnv(const char* flag, const char* default_val);
